title: AP itemization feels so lackluster compared to AD
body:
I remember when I felt powerful playing AP champions. Why is it necessary to make AP carries fall off lategame? (With the exception of a few) Also, why are AP items always having their AP reduced over and over again?

Long story short, I don't enjoy playing AP champions that much anymore. I used to main almost all of them. Here's a list of champions that I've completely stopped playing because of various reasons : {{champion:1}} {{champion:136}} {{champion:268}} {{champion:7}} {{champion:90}} {{champion:163}} {{champion:161}} {{champion:112}} {{champion:115}} {{champion:143}} 

Nowadays I enjoy playing top lane a lot more than mid. Playing bruisers make me feel impactful and powerful. I don't want to rely on hitting an Orianna RW lategame and not even denting half their health unless I snowballed out of control in the first place. 

If you think AP champions are worth playing for reasons other than team needs AP damage, please do share it with me. 

Sincerely,
A sad mid lane main.

replies.body:
The MR per level changes were pretty substantial and I think people are ignoring them. 

By level 18 you get a free 9MR, that's enough to nullify the most common 7.8 Mpen taken in runes, which I'd say is pretty big.

I feel consistently like I'm dealing enough DPS as an AP champ, but the fall-off still happens due to durability and sticking power. If you can't live long enough to land a couple spells, the general pattern is that you of course will fall off. The sticking power point is that other items scale too well. ADCs who can out-lifesteal a 1k nuke is definitely a concern.

Shields and health are particularly more of a counter for AP mages in a sense, because a nuke will deal "X" damage (reduced by MR). It then has to wait to be cast again. That wait period in early-to-mid game is a bit more consistent with the dps you need/want to be dealing, maybe not game-breaking, but certainly impacting. A 500 damage nuke on a 6 second cooldown sounds hefty, but the rate of fire means if it doesn't kill, the enemy can then retaliate, regenerate, mitigate and/or retreat. It's not that you're looking for an assassin pattern of a fast kill, but you certainly want to be able to hit again and actually kill on the 2nd or 3rd set of output you dish out. This doesn't happen so fluidly.

Supports and Mages generally are your prime targets since they ideally are the targets on level footing. The items they have available are the same ones you probably can get to counter them. It's weird, because health is the counter-all. So Rylai's, RoA, GLP and Protobelt provide in that regard, but the more you analyze it's not quite the same efficiency as other roles have. Zhonya's doesn't really compel consistent engagement, more of an "oh crap" button than anything. You get a couple seconds on your cooldowns, but generally are put sitting duck. Boots? As a counter, they aren't really the most efficient choice, but sometimes you just have to. Liandry's makes for health melting goodness, but as a DoT you both need the magic pen and the CC through probably rylai's to make it count all while giving up sustain that other classes don't.

{{item:3135}} is a weird one. It technically has more gold value than a Deathcap. Think about that for a second. It's dps-granting powers come from the Magic Pen which allows you to hit closer to the true dps-value of a spell. Your spell can read that it will deal 500 damage, but 100 MR will make that deal 250 damage without MPen. Void staff mitigates the effects of MR in this sense.

The only items I can 100% say work in a sense are Luden's and Morello's. One gives base power combined with utility of a splash to a spell and the other gives enough base stats to keep someone running for a while before you even consider the passive, which is necessary to counter a heal-based player, but also relies on a health threshold that people can sometimes avoid dropping below. (Though it wouldn't necessarily be fair or balanced if it was applied before the current threshhold.)

It's not easy to explain exactly what's wrong with itemization for mages, but here's the core points:

* **Utility.** Uniques abilities items have, need to work for intended use or have an additional use to begin with.
* **Sustain/Durability**. AP caster items lack a certain edge if you're looking for it.
* **Synergy**. If you analyze what works about the items other classes use, you'll notice a lot more effects on items that kinda chain together. Synergy as a point is a weird one though. It's not that all the items don't have a certain synergy individually, only that the total composite effects could use some work, so that a complete item has more impact than buying a similarly priced component item.

You're right it is. But that's because the reason behind itemization is different per type of champion.

Look at adc's, their job is pretty much right click in a various way. Now while ADC's may be diverse in how they do something (Jhin and Ashe Utility, Cait range, Vayne KILL ability) their job still boils down into Right click, with some left clicks thrown in as well. Now, from a Mid lane perspective, that can be pretty boring sometimes, so they diversify by giving them options for build. 

The Various AS items help choose what type of ADC ya want, or something to compensate. Statick and Fireshot for extra damage, Static and Runaans for waveclear, Fireshot and PD for some added survival etc. Various Lifesteals for what you want to do (BT for drain tanking, Mecurial for safety, BorK for tank killing) and you have your CDR combo for those Crit builds who might also like CDR (IE, Essence). Playing ADC is almost like a Build-a-bear workshop, where you get a baseline, and then you can build it the way you want, or a do it yourself dessert shop. 

Mages are different because their variability are in their actual kit. They range from a numerous amount of things from Range, Zone control, LOTSA damage, CC, tank killing, etc. with the only common factor being Damage. They don't need itemization to become unique, because they're already unique in their own way. They're that ice cream you buy at [Salt & Straw](http://saltandstraw.com/flavors/), they're already unique enough where they don't need items to vary up gameplay. 

ADC's get variation in items because they're right click, Mages don't because their job is concrete in what they do, and how they do it. They're meant to be a more strict "You do this very well" Class, unlike ADC who is "You can do this very well in various ways" since ADC's come on later in the game usually.
